questions.text: A 9-month-old female infant presents with failure to thrive, repeated respiratory infections, and anemia refractory to administration of cobalamin, pyridoxine, folic acid, and iron (Figure A). Urinalysis demonstrates a crystalline sediment and a blood test shows normal ammonia levels. Which of the following enzymes is defective in this infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The presentation of failure to thrive, refractory megaloblastic anemia, crystalluria, and a normal blood ammonia level is suggestive of defective UMP synthase in the de novo pyrimidine synthesis pathway resulting in orotic aciduria.

Orotic aciduria is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting from a defect in the bifunctional enzyme UMP synthase (orotate phosphoribosyltransferase and orotidine-5'-phosphate decarboxylase) that prevents the conversion of orotic acid to uridine monophosphate (UMP). This inability to produce UMP prevents the de novo synthesis of pyrimidine bases; therefore, there is a lack of pyrimidine bases and DNA cannot replicate. In ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC) deficiency, there is also a build up of orotic acid, but OTC deficiency also presents with hyperammonemia, which is missing in orotic aciduria.

Figure A shows a blood smear with macrocytosis and the characteristic hypersegmented neutrophils with up to 8 lobes versus the normal 3 to 4. Illustration A demonstrates a normal blood smear with a normally segmented neutrophil with 3 to 4 lobes.

Incorrect Answers: 
Answer 1: Ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC) is involved in the urea cycle catalyzing the reaction between carbamoyl phosphate and ornithine to form citrulline. Patients with OTC deficiency present with a decreased BUN, elevated orotic acid levels in the blood and urine with symptoms of hyperammonemia.

Answer 2: Adenosine deaminase (ADA) is involved in the conversion of adenosine to inosine. Patients with a deficiency in ADA present with a decrease in lymphocytes and have severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID).

Answer 3: Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) is involved in the purine salvage pathway converting guanine to guanylic acid and hypoxanthine to inosinic acid. Patients with a deficiency in HGPRT present with an increase in uric acid in the blood and urine and display symptoms of gout, aggression, retardation, and self-mutilation.

Answer 4: Xanthine oxidase is involved in the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and finally to uric acid. Although a very rare condition, patients with a deficiency in xanthine oxidase have high levels of xanthine in the blood and urine and can present with xanthine kidney stones and renal failure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to her primary care physician with a chief complaint of easy bruising and bleeding over the last 6 months. She has also noticed that she has been having fatty, foul smelling stools. Past history is significant for cholecystectomy a year ago to treat a long history of symptomatic gallstones. Based on clinical suspicion a coagulation panel was obtained showing a prothrombin time (PT) of 18 seconds (normal range 9-11 seconds), a partial thromboplastin time (PTT) of 45 seconds (normal 20-35 seconds), with a normal ristocetin cofactor assay (modern equivalent of bleeding time). Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vitamin K deficiency

The most likely diagnosis in this case is vitamin K deficiency secondary to fat malabsorption following cholecystectomy.

Vitamin K is used as a cofactor for gamma-carboxylation of glutamic acid residues on factors of the coagulation cascade. These factors are II, VII, IX, and X. Deficiency of vitamin K can therefore cause improper processing of many coagulation factors leading to a combined direct and indirect pathway defect. This is manifested as an increased PT and increased PTT. The most common causes of vitamin K deficiency are lack of absorption in the GI tract or lack of activation in liver insufficiency.

The way to approach a question on bleeding is to first establish whether the problem affects the coagulation cascade, platelet aggregation, or both mechanisms. Coagulation disorders typically lead to deep bleeding, while platelet disorders typically lead to petechiae and purpura. The corresponding tests are PT (measuring extrinsic pathway), PTT (measuring intrinsic pathway) and ristocetin cofactor analysis / bleeding time measuring platelets. In this case there is a combined intrinsic/extrinsic pathway disorder, which can be due to a common pathway disorder, anticoagulant overdose, or carboxylation defects. The history of fat malabsorption and subacute onset lead towards the diagnosis of vitamin K deficiency.

Incorrect Answers:

Answer 1: Hemophilia is caused by a deficiency in intrinsic pathway coagulation factors and therefore would lead to an isolated prolongation of PTT without affecting PT.

Answer 2: ITP is an isolated platelet deficiency and would have an abnormal ristocetin cofactor with a normal PT/PTT.
Answer 3: Rat poison is actually warfarin, an inhibitor of gamma carboxylation and so it can present with this exact pattern of findings; however, the onset of poisoning would be acute bleeding rather than this pattern of a slow 6 month onset. The surrounding clinical details of cholecystectomy and malabsorption is also suggestive of another diagnosis
Answer 5: von Willebrand Factor is important for both platelet aggregation and for coagulation due to its binding of factor VIII. It would therefore lead to a prolonged PTT and bleeding time with no effect on PT.

The most common causes of vitamin K deficiency can be divided into malabsorptive syndromes, poor diet, or pharmacologic vitamin K chelators and inhibitors. Malabsorption can be due to bacterial overgrowth, celiac disease, chronic pancreatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, or short-gut syndrome. The most common drug that binds vitamin K and prevents its processing is cholestyramine. (1)

questions.text: 47-year-old man has an ejection fraction of 0.32 and an end-diastolic volume of 160 ml. What is (approximately) the value of end-systolic volume?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ejection fraction (EF) is calculated as follows: stroke volume (SV)/end-diastolic volume (EDV) multiplied by 100 and expressed in percent. If the EF of this patients is 0.32, that means 32%. If the end diastolic volume is 160, then 0.32 of that value will represent the stroke volume (SV), and subtracting the SV from EDV will result in the end systolic volume, which is exactly 108.8 ml (approximately 109 ml).

questions.text: A 33-year-old marathon runner sweats heavily as core temperature increases. What feedback mechanism is involved?
questions.solution:

Increased core temperature triggers thermoregulatory responses (sweating, vasodilation) that oppose the temperature rise — negative feedback.

questions.text: The equation which is used to calculate the magnitude of the equilibrium potential of an ion is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Nernst Equation- Donnan and Gibbs showed that in the presence of a non diffusible ion, the diffusible ions distribute themselves so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal. This is the Gibbs Donnan Equation.
If a membrane is freely permeable to an ion, magnitude of potential difference for that ion at equilibrium (equilibrium potential or Nernst potential) can be calculated by the Nernst Equation.  Goldmann Hodgkin Katz equation is used to calculate the RMP.
Henderson Hasselbach equation is used to calculate the pH of a buffer solution containing given concentrations of an acid and its conjugate base.

questions.text: The channels present in glomus cells which respond to hypoxia are for which of the following ions?

The channels present in glomus cells of the carotid and aortic bodies which respond to hypoxia are O2 sensitive potassium channels. Hypoxia causes closure of these channel, increasing the intracellular potassium which in turn depolarizes the cell resulting in increased release of the neurotransmitter Dopamine.

questions.text: Which drug blocks the insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) and is used in the treatment of thyroid eye disease (TED)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation of Options:
• A. Pegvisomant – A growth hormone receptor (GHR) antagonist used in the treatment of acromegaly. It does not act on IGF-1R.
• B. Mecasermin – A recombinant human IGF-1 analog, used in severe primary IGF-1 deficiency. It actually activates IGF-1R, not blocks it.
• C. Teprotumumab – A monoclonal antibody that blocks IGF-1R. This prevents orbital fibroblast activation and reduces inflammation, adipogenesis, and tissue remodeling in thyroid eye disease (TED). 
• D. Teplizumab – An anti-CD3 monoclonal antibody, used in delaying the onset of type 1 diabetes, not related to IGF-1R or TED.

questions.text: Which of the following opioids is contraindicated in patients taking MAO inhibitors due to the risk of life-threatening interactions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Meperidine

Explanation
• Pethidine (Meperidine) when combined with MAO inhibitors (e.g., phenelzine, tranylcypromine, selegiline):
o Leads to serotonin syndrome (excess serotonin in CNS).
o Features: agitation, tremor, hyperthermia, seizures, hypertension, coma, death.
o This reaction is well-documented and highly dangerous, hence pethidine is absolutely contraindicated with MAO inhibitors.
• Morphine, Buprenorphine, Pentazocine:
o Can be used cautiously with dose monitoring.
o They don’t cause the same severe serotonin toxicity as pethidine.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with chronic asthma is prescribed two bronchodilators. Drug A produces 80% of the maximum possible bronchodilation at a low dose. Drug B produces 100% bronchodilation but requires a higher dose. Which is correct?

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF, EF 35%), along with type 2 diabetes and chronic kidney disease (CKD). She is already on standard therapy with a β-blocker and a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (MRA).Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate to add for additional benefit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dapagliflozin

 Explanation
• Dapagliflozin (SGLT2 inhibitor)
o Proven to reduce HF hospitalizations and CV death in HFrEF patients, with or without diabetes (DAPA-HF trial, EMPEROR-Reduced trial).
o Provides added benefit in patients with diabetes + CKD — improves renal outcomes (DAPA-CKD trial).
o Well tolerated and now a Class I recommendation in 2022 AHA/ACC/HFSA & ESC guidelines for HFrEF.
• Sacubitril/Valsartan (ARNI)
o Strong mortality benefit (PARADIGM-HF trial).
o Excellent choice if patient was on an ACEi/ARB previously, but in a diabetic with CKD, risk of hyperkalemia & worsening renal function requires caution.
o Can still be used, but dapagliflozin has additional renal + diabetic benefits here.
• Vericiguat
o Stimulates soluble guanylate cyclase (↑ cGMP).
o Approved for worsening HFrEF despite optimal therapy (VICTORIA trial).
o Used later in advanced/refractory cases, not as first add-on here.
• Omecamtiv mecarbil
o Cardiac myosin activator (GALACTIC-HF trial).
o Investigational/limited use, not first-line and not guideline Class I yet.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on his first hemodialysis session suddenly develops headache, nausea, confusion, and seizures during the procedure. On examination, he is hypertensive and drowsy. CT scan of the brain is normal.  This presentation is most consistent with dialysis disequilibrium syndrome (DDS).  Which of the following pharmacological measures is most appropriate for managing this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mannitol IV

Explanation:
• Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS):
o Occurs during or after hemodialysis, especially first or rapid dialysis in patients with very high urea.
o Pathophysiology: Rapid removal of urea from plasma → water moves into brain cells (due to osmotic gradient) → cerebral edema, raised intracranial pressure.
o Clinical features: Headache, nausea, vomiting, agitation, confusion, seizures, coma.
• Treatment:
o Mannitol IV (osmotic diuretic) or Hypertonic saline may be used to reduce cerebral edema.
o Mannitol is the first-line drug because it effectively pulls water out of brain cells.
o Prevention: slow and gentle dialysis, sodium modeling, using smaller dialyzer.
• Other options:
o Dexamethasone: not standard therapy, only useful if cerebral edema due to inflammation/tumor.
o Hypertonic saline: sometimes used, but mannitol is preferred.
o Furosemide: acts on kidneys, useless in ESRD patient.

questions.text:
A 25-day-old infant is brought with paroxysmal cough followed by inspiratory “whoop” and post-tussive vomiting. The baby has apneic episodes during coughing bouts.

The diagnosis of pertussis (whooping cough) is confirmed by PCR for Bordetella pertussis.  Which of the following is the best antibiotic choice for this infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Azithromycin

Explanation
• Macrolides (erythromycin, azithromycin, clarithromycin) are the drugs of choice for pertussis.
• Erythromycin is effective but contraindicated in <1 month infants because it increases risk of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).
• Clarithromycin is also not preferred in neonates due to limited safety data.
• Amoxicillin has no role against Bordetella pertussis.
• Azithromycin is the preferred drug in infants <1 month because:
o Equally effective
o Safer (no IHPS risk)
o Shorter duration of therapy (5 days vs 14 days for erythro).

Key Exam Point
• DOC Pertussis = Macrolides
• <1 month → Azithromycin
• ≥1 month → Azithromycin / Erythromycin / Clarithromycin all acceptable
• Supportive care critical in neonates (risk of apnea, pneumonia, sudden death).

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with metastatic prostate cancer is started on medical androgen deprivation therapy (ADT). He initially receives a GnRH agonist injection but later develops worsening bone pain and urinary obstruction. His oncologist explains that this is due to a transient testosterone surge (“tumor flare”). Which additional drug should be given to prevent this complication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bicalutamide

Explanation
• GnRH agonists (like leuprolide) initially stimulate the pituitary to release LH and FSH, causing a transient surge in testosterone levels.
• This surge can temporarily worsen symptoms in patients with metastatic prostate cancer (tumor flare).
• To prevent this, a non-steroidal anti-androgen (e.g., bicalutamide, flutamide) is given before and during the first few weeks of GnRH agonist therapy.
• Abiraterone is a CYP17 inhibitor that suppresses androgen synthesis but is not used for tumor flare prevention.
• Finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor used for BPH, not for tumor flare.
• Leuprolide is itself a GnRH agonist; it causes the flare.

questions.text: Which monoclonal antibody binds PD-1 receptor on activated T-cells, thereby enhancing antitumor immunity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Nivolumab 

Explanation
• PD-1 (Programmed cell death protein-1) is a checkpoint receptor on activated T-cells.
• Tumor cells often exploit this pathway (via PD-L1/PD-L2 binding to PD-1) to suppress T-cell activity and evade the immune system.
• Nivolumab (and Pembrolizumab) are anti–PD-1 monoclonal antibodies → they block PD-1 on T-cells → restore T-cell activation → enhance antitumor immunity.

Other options:
• Durvalumab → anti–PD-L1 antibody.
• Atezolizumab → anti–PD-L1 antibody.
• Trastuzumab → anti-HER2 antibody (used in HER2+ breast and gastric cancers).

questions.text: Match the drugs listed in Column A with their correct clinical indications from Column B:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Correct Matching with Explanation:
A. Fezolinetant → 2. Moderate-to-severe vasomotor symptoms
o Fezolinetant is a neurokinin-3 (NK3) receptor antagonist.
o FDA approved in 2023 for treatment of moderate-to-severe vasomotor symptoms (hot flashes) associated with menopause.
B. Xanomeline → 4. Schizophrenia
o Xanomeline (a muscarinic M1/M4 receptor agonist), often studied in combination with trospium, has shown benefit in schizophrenia by targeting cholinergic pathways.
o Represents a novel non-dopaminergic antipsychotic approach.
C. Donanemab → 1. Alzheimer’s disease
o Donanemab is an anti-amyloid monoclonal antibody.
o It targets amyloid-β plaques in the brain and is under investigation/approval for early symptomatic Alzheimer’s disease.
D. Trofinetide → 3. Rett syndrome
o Trofinetide is a synthetic analog of IGF-1.
o FDA approved in 2023 as the first drug for Rett syndrome, a rare neurodevelopmental disorder in girls.
Option 5 (Breast cancer) → Not applicable to these listed drugs.

questions.text:
Compared to tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF), Tenofovir Alafenamide (TAF) has less adverse effects of 
A. Ostemalacia 
B. Nephrotoxicity
C. Weight gain
D. Dyslipidaemia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation

• Tenofovir Disoproxil Fumarate (TDF):
o Older prodrug of tenofovir.
o Associated with renal toxicity (proximal tubular injury → Fanconi syndrome, proteinuria, increased creatinine) and bone toxicity (osteomalacia, decreased bone mineral density).

• Tenofovir Alafenamide (TAF):
o A newer prodrug, more stable in plasma, delivers tenofovir more efficiently inside lymphocytes and hepatocytes.
o This means lower plasma concentrations → less renal and bone toxicity compared to TDF.

Side effect profile:
• TDF → more renal + bone adverse effects.
• TAF → less renal/bone toxicity but can cause weight gain and dyslipidemia (metabolic adverse effects).

questions.text: Which is not available at village level?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Zila panchayat
Explanation
The administrative system in Indian villages is primarily structured around the Panchayati Raj system, a form of local self-governance. It's a three-tiered structure, with the Gram Panchayat at the village level being the foundational unit. This system ensures that villagers have a direct say in their local governance and development. 
A. Gram Panchayat:
• This is the basic unit of local administration in rural India, often referred to as a village council or village panchayat. 
• It's responsible for the governance and administration of a village or a group of villages. 
• Members are directly elected by the villagers, ensuring democratic representation. 
• The Gram Panchayat handles local issues like sanitation, water supply, roads, and basic infrastructure. 
B. Panchayat Samiti (Block Panchayat):
• Located at the block level, this acts as an intermediate tier in the Panchayati Raj system.
• It coordinates and oversees the activities of the Gram Panchayats within its jurisdiction.
• Members are indirectly elected from the Gram Panchayats. 
C. Zila Parishad (District Panchayat):
• This is the highest tier of the Panchayati Raj system, functioning at the district level.
• It provides overall guidance and supervision to the Panchayat Samitis and Gram Panchayats.
• Like the Panchayat Samiti, its members are indirectly elected. 
The Gram Sabha is the general assembly of all adults registered to vote in a village, while the Gram Panchayat is a smaller, elected body that acts as the executive arm for village development. Essentially, the Gram Sabha is the larger body that oversees and approves the work of the Gram Panchayat. 
A Nyaya Panchayat is a village-level dispute resolution body in India's Panchayati Raj system, focused on providing accessible and affordable justice for minor civil and criminal cases. They act as an alternative to formal courts, aiming for speedy and local resolution through conciliation and compromise.

questions.text: Match the following considering “Benjamin and Inglis classification of laryngeal clefts”
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

1b 2a 3d 4c.
Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
Benjamin and Inglis classification of laryngeal clefts 
 Type 1: supraglottic interarytenoid cleft, sparing the cricoid cartilage. 
Type 2: partial cricoid cleft, remains above the cricoid lamina. 
Type 3: total cricoid cleft, with or without extension into the cervical cartilage. 
Type 4: laryngoesophageal cleft, extending into the thoracic trachea, may extend as far as carina

• Surgical repair must be taken in all cases of symptomatic clefts. 
• Type I clefts can sometimes be managed nonsurgically with speech and feeding therapy aimed towards decreasing aspiration. GERD must be controlled. When conservative measures fail to prevent aspiration, endoscopic or open repair of the cleft may be possible. 
• Type II and III clefts can be approached via an anterior laryngofissure or a lateral pharyngotomy. A tracheotomy and two-layer closure are then performed. 
• Type IV clefts require a lateral pharyngotomy and right thoracotomy or a midline anterior approach with a median sternotomy with the patient on cardiac bypass.

questions.text: Air embolism is a complication of which surgical position?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fowler's position increases the risk of venous air embolism (VAE) during surgery because the head-elevated position can create negative pressure in the veins, drawing air into the bloodstream, especially during neurosurgical and ENT procedures.
To prevent VAE in Fowler's position, use saline-soaked dressings, and consider head-down positioning if possible to reduce negative venous pressure. If an air embolism occurs, the procedure should be stopped, 100% oxygen administered, and a jugular venous compression applied to prevent further air entry
• Risk of air embolism is more (Risk of venous air embolism is more when site of surgery is 5 cm above heart)
• In case foramen ovale is patent it can lead to paradoxical embolism leading to corornary or cerebral ischemia
• The fatal amount of air in human is reported to be either 200 and 300 ml bolus or 3-5 ml/kg

questions.text: Lethal triad includes all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The lethal triad, also known as the trauma triad of death, refers to a critical combination of hypothermia (low body temperature), acidosis (excessive acidity in the blood), and coagulopathy (impaired blood clotting) seen in trauma patients.
In trauma patients, hypothermia is clinically defined as a reduction in the core body temperature to levels below 35 °C (95 °F). Acidosis is a critical condition in trauma care characterized by a blood pH level of less than 7.35. 
The causes of trauma-induced coagulopathy include tissue trauma, shock, and inflammation. These factors initiate a cascade of events leading to coagulation impairment. Trauma-induced coagulopathy is often exacerbated by iatrogenic factors, including fluid administration, hypothermia, metabolic acidosis, and dilutional coagulopathy, any of which may be the result of resuscitation efforts.

questions.text: A patient presented with 2 cm nodule in thyroid with high calcitonin without any palpable node. What should be the ideal treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

MEDULLARY THYROID CARCINOMA: 5%
• It can be associated with other endocrine tumors – MEN II A and B
• F> M. (except for inherited cancers). Commonest in 5th – 6th decades. >50% are bilateral.
• Regional metastases (spread to neck lymph nodes) occurs early in the disease
• Spread to distant organs (metastasis) occurs late and can be to the liver, bone, brain, and adrenal medulla
• Diarrhoea is common 
• FNAC shows amyloid stroma.
• Usually originates in the upper central lobe of the thyroid
• Poor prognostic factors include age >50, male, distant spread (metastases), and when seen in patients with other endocrine tumors due to MEN II-B syndrome.
• Residual disease (following surgery) or recurrence can be detected by measuring calcitonin (a hormone that should be measured every 4 months for the first few years and then every 6 months for ever).
• 20% of patients acquire this through autosomal dominant inherited pattern.
• Germ line abnormality of chromosome 10 (pericentrometric region) is related to 3 different familial pattern (MEN II a, MEN II b, and non MEN medullayr carcinoma).
• MCT associated with MEN are multicentric, in younger age and associated with C cell hyperplasia.
• MTC is screened by Pantagastrin stimulated or calcium stimulated plasma level of calcitonin.
• Metastasis is through lymphatics and blood vessels (Liver).
• Though calcitonin is high but hypercalcemia is not a notable feature.  
• Prognosis is worse in: Older patients, MEN II b, large tumour size, Lymph node mets and distant metastasis.
• Treatment: Total thyroidectomy with central node dissection. If neck nodes are positive or big tumour than Radical neck dissection should be done.
• “Prophylactic Total thyroidectomy is indicated in RET positive (MEN syndrome) in childhood. In MEN 2a it is done < 5 years while in MEN 2b it is done < 1 years”. If calcitonin is high than central neck dissection can be added with total thyroidectomy.
• In setting of Familial MCT patient with basal or stimulated calcitonin relative should undergo a total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection
• It is important to screen for catecholamine excess prior to surgical exploration to rule out familial syndrome with an occult pheochromocytoma.
• Radio-I has no role in treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in the treatment of thyrotoxic crisis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Dantrolene is used to treat malignant hyperthermia crisis. It is a specific antagonist that helps to reverse the uncontrolled calcium release in muscle cells. 
Malignant hyperthermia (MH) is a rare, inherited muscle disorder that causes a severe reaction to certain inhaled anesthetics and muscle relaxants (Succinylcholine). Symptoms include a rapid and dangerous rise in body temperature, muscle rigidity, rapid heart rate, and increased carbon dioxide production.
It is differentiated from thyrotoxic storm by muscle rigidity, acidosis, high CPK and rhabdomyolysis.

questions.text: A patient presented with occasional mild bleeding per-rectum, Colonoscopy was done which showed vascular malformation in Caecum (picture below). He is also having Aortic stenosis and Von-willi brand factor deficiency. This patient is suffering from?

VASCULAR ANOMALIES (ANGIODYSPLASIA)
• Angiodysplasia is a vascular malformation associated with ageing, kind of degenerative disorder and is second most common cause of colonic bleed (Diverticulosis being first).

• Clinical features
i. In the majority, the symptoms are subtle and patients can present with anaemia.

questions.text: Howship Romberg sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Obturator hernia: nickname- “little old lady's hernia.”
• Obturator hernia proceeds through the obturator foramen situated at the anterolateral pelvic wall, interiorly to the acetabulum. 
• Typically obturator hernias occur in elderly women or patients with chronically raised intra-abdominal pressure (e.g. ascites, COPD, chronic cough).  
• Female : Male - 6:1. Right : Left – 3:1
• The Howship–Romberg sign: Seen in 50%. Intermittent, acute, and severe hyperesthesia or pain in the medial thigh or in the region of the greater trochanter, usually relieved by thigh flexion and worsened by medial rotation, adduction, or extension at the hip
• The Hannington–Kiff sign, a clinical sign in which there is an absent adductor reflux in the thigh (more specific). 
• Other symptoms include acute or intermittent small bowel obstruction with high risk of strangulation
• Generally approached abdominally and often amenable to laparoscopic repair; mesh closure is necessary for a tension-free repair
• Strangulated obturator hernias carry the highest mortality rate of all abdominal hernias

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with chronic back pain, evening rise of temperature, and weight loss. X-ray spine shows destruction of the anterior vertebral body with reduced disc space at the thoracolumbar junction. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tuberculosis of spine

Explanation:
 • TB spine (Pott’s disease):
 • Common at thoracolumbar junction.
 • Features: anterior vertebral body destruction, disc space narrowing, paravertebral abscess.
 • Systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss) help differentiate from metastasis.
 • Pyogenic spondylitis: usually acute, more pain, high fever.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents with pain around the knee, worse at night, not relieved by aspirin. X-ray shows a metaphyseal lesion in the distal femur with a “sunburst pattern” and Codman’s triangle. Most likely diagnosis?

Osteosarcoma

Explanation:
 • Most common primary malignant bone tumor in adolescents.
 • Location: metaphysis of long bones, esp. around knee.
 • Radiology: sunburst pattern, Codman’s triangle (periosteal elevation).
 • Pain not relieved by aspirin (unlike osteoid osteoma).

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with thigh pain and swelling after a road traffic accident. X-ray shows a mid-shaft femur fracture. On the 3rd day of admission, he suddenly develops breathlessness, tachycardia, and petechial rash over the chest. Most likely diagnosis?

Fat embolism syndrome

Explanation:
 • Classic triad: respiratory distress, neurological signs, and petechial rash.
 • Seen in long bone fractures (femur, tibia, pelvis).
 • Onset: usually 24–72 hrs after trauma.
 • Pulmonary embolism does not cause petechial rash.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male undergoes a rapid sequence induction to secure his airway for emergency trauma surgery to fix multiple limb fractures following a serious motorcycle accident. He is very cold and venous access was very difficult in A&E. As the thiopentone is injected into his left hand, the patient cries out in pain and his arm becomes suddenly very pale and cyanosed. What is the most suitable analgesic method to control this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

• Intra-arterial injection of drugs is, thankfully, very rare. 
• Where it occurs, it is because of inadvertent injection into an arterial line, or injection into a venous line that is inadvertently in an artery. 
• It is more likely to occur in the hypotensive, cold, peripherally shut-down patient, such as the one in the question.
• An early symptom is pain and discomfort on injection of an irritant drug. Patients with distracting injuries, sedation, anaesthesia, or depressed consciousness are at risk. 
• The drug will fail to have its desired effect, and limb pain, paraesthesia, pallor, hyperaemia, and cyanosis can occur. 
• Damage is thought to occur due to arterial spasm, direct tissue destruction by the drug, subsequent chemical arteritis causing endothelial destruction, release of thromboxane, and drug precipitation and crystallization.
• Management strategies aim to maintain perfusion distal to the injection. Elevation improves venous drainage, anticoagulation prevents thrombosis, and analgesia is imperative. 
• Stellate ganglion block interrupts the sympathetic supply to the limb, producing arterial and venous vasodilation, and analgesia. \
• Intra-arterial lignocaine may prevent reflex vasospasm but can cause damage itself. 
• Methylprednisolone and papaverine reverse tissue ischaemia, but do not immediately provide analgesia. 
• Interscalene brachial plexus block will provide analgesia, but not sympathetic blockade.

choices.text: Is derived from pure cis isomer of atracurium
Is eliminated predominantly via Hoffman degradation
Is associated with no histamine release.
May be preferred over atracurium in epileptic patients as it is not metabolized to laudanosine

questions.text: Cisatracurium all are true except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

• Cisatatracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker in the benzylisoquinolinium class. 
• It is derived from a single cis isomer of the parent molecule atracurium, of which it comprises approximately 15%. 
• It was manufactured to produce a ‘cleaner’ drug without associated histamine release, and there are no such side effects with cisatracurium. 
• The majority (up to 80%) of the drug is eliminated via Hofmann degradation, which is temperature and pH dependent 
• Like atracurium, laudanosine is a recognized metabolite. 
• This tertiary amine is a known CNS stimulant
• Cisatracurium is more potent than atracurium
• However, onset of muscle relaxation is slower than atracurium, in equipotent doses 
• Duration of action is similar for both drugs.

choices.text: The second gas effect is seen during the anaesthesia induction phase.
Rapid uptake of new gas from alveolus results in increased concentration of all other gases within alveolus.
2nd gas effect causes delayed onset of action of an inhaled anesthetic agent.
This effect is seen with only nitrous oxide and xenon.

questions.text: Regarding the second gas effect when using inhalation anaesthetic agents, all are true except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Second gas effect
• A high concentration of (newly introduced) gas in the alveolus results in rapid uptake of the gas into pulmonary capillary blood, down its concentration gradient. 
• Rapid uptake of new gas from the alveolus results in increased concentration of all other gases within the alveolus.
• Starting to inspire a high concentration of N 2 O results in rapid rate of rise of N 2 O concentration in FRC, and an equally rapid rate of rise of alveolar concentration for all newly introduced gases given concomitantly. 
• These other gases will be both concentrated and subjected to increased Volatile Anesthetic , and so have a faster rate of rise of alveolar concentration than if given alone.
• This causes faster onset of induction of an inhaled anesthetic agent when used along with nitrous oxide.

choices.text: It can distinguish between causes of decreased brain activity
It predicts movement to surgical stimulus
Higher values represent more cortical activity

questions.text: Regarding the bispectral index (BIS):
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

• The bispectral index is a statistically based, empirically derived complex parameter. 
• It is a weighted sum of several EEG parameters and provides the user with a dimensionless number which ranges from 0 (equivalent to EEG silence) to 100 (normal cortical electrical activity). 
• It records the cortical activity of a patient’s brain and, using analysis, gives a raw figure, higher values representing higher levels of cortical activity
• BIS is best described as a monitor of the depth of the hypnotic component of anaesthesia or sedation. 
• Bispectral index values
• 80–100 Awake, capable of specific recall
• 60–80 Increased sedation, impaired memory but rousable
• 40–60 Surgical plane of anaesthesia. Auditory processing and reflex movement are possible, but memory unlikely
• 60-40 deep hypnotic state
• 40-20 Burst suppression
• 0 flat line (eeg silence)
• BIS values only give an idea of cortical activity – they cannot distinguish whether a low value is due to anaesthesia or pathological causes of reduced consciousness.

questions.text: A 63-year-old lady is scheduled for total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophrectomy under general anaesthesia. She is an insulin-dependent diabetic and has Parkinson’s disease, treated with levodopa. What would be the most appropriate combination of antiemetics for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

• Parkinson’s disease is a neurological disease of the extrapyramidal system. 
• It is thought to be due to loss of dopaminergic neurones in the substantia nigra, which causes an imbalance of acetyl choline and dopamine. 
• It is treated with drugs to increase available dopamine substrate, using dopamine precursors (e.g. levodopa), dopamine agonists (e.g. apomorphine), and monoamine oxidase inhibitors (e.g. selegiline).
• Anti-emetic drugs are designed to act at a number of receptors throughout the central nervous system, vomiting centres, vestibular centres, and on the gut. 
• One subtype of antiemetic is the dopamine receptor antagonists. Metoclopramide, droperidol, and prochlorperazine all act as dopamine anatagonists, and can therefore worsen the symptoms of Parkinson’s disease.
• Dexamethasone is used as an antiemetic agent, although its mechanism of action remains unclear. 
• However, in this case, using a steroid as an antiemetic may cause derangement of the blood glucose, and impair glycaemic control in the post-operative period. For that reason it is best avoided in the insulin dependent diabetic.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered as the strongest predictor of suicide?

questions.text: A 23-year old man impulsively steals a pack of gum at a convenience store. He has never stolen anything previously, and almost immediately upon exiting the store with the gum, he begins to feel extremely guilty. Which of the following concepts introduced by Freud is most likely responsible for this man’s emotional response to his theft?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Superego
 In his structural theory of the mind, Freud divided the psychic apparatus into three agencies: the id, which contains the instinctual drives; the ego, whose function is to find an equilibrium between gratification of the instinctual drives and the rules of society (and the demands of the superego); and the superego, the agency that contains the internalized parental and societal rules and dictates to the ego what is not to be done. Guilt is the consequence of transgressing the superego’s prohibitions. Preconscious and conscious functions are dimensions of the ego.

questions.text: Two brothers have been fighting. Exasperated, the mother says to one of her sons, "Go to your room until you apologize to your brother for hitting him!" The mother's words are an example of the application of:

Negative reinforcement 

In the given example, “go to your room, until you apologize” increases the desired behaviour (apologizing) in the son. Hence this is an example of negative reinforcement.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is deeply envious of his younger but much more successful brother. Although it is difficult for him to admit, he believes the younger brother was their parents’ favorite as well. He tells his friends that his younger brother is envious of his good looks and successes with women, even though there is some evidence that this is not so. Identify the defense mechanism used.

Projection 
 In the given example the elder brother projects, his own inner unacceptable feelings (envy) on to his younger brother unconsciously. This is an example of the defense mechanism of projection.

questions.text: Fixation of “Dependent personality disorder” is at which stage of psychosexual development :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Oral 
(Ref : Kaplan Psychiatry Pg 743)
 Sigmund Freud suggested that personality traits are related to a fixation at one psychosexual stage of development. For example, those with an oral character are passive and dependent because they are fixated at the oral stage, when the dependence on others for food is prominent. Those with an anal character are stubborn, parsimonious, and highly conscientious because of struggles over toilet training during the anal period.

questions.text: A newborn with 46,XY DSD has a palpable gonad in the inguinal canal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome

Explanation: Palpable gonads in 46 XY DSD suggest testes, common in partial androgen insensitivity syndrome (PAIS), causing ambiguous genitalia. Mixed gonadal dysgenesis may have streak gonads, complete dysgenesis lacks functional gonads, and ovo-testicular DSD is rare.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with hot flashes and mood swings. She is 1 year postmenopausal. She asks about alternatives to hormone replacement therapy (HRT). What is a non-hormonal alternative that can be considered?

SSRIs

Explanation: SSRIs (Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors) are effective for managing hot flashes and mood swings in menopausal women and are a non-hormonal alternative to HRT.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate ovulation induction agent for PCOS?
questions.solution:

Letrozole

Explanation: Letrozole is first-line for ovulation induction in PCOS, with higher live birth rates than clomiphene, per FOGSI guidelines.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding for 6 months. What is the most likely structural cause of AUB?
questions.solution:

Leiomyoma

Leiomyoma (fibroids) is a common structural cause (PALM: AUB-L) of heavy menstrual bleeding, especially in women aged 30s–40s, per FIGO and FOGSI guidelines.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with primary dysmenorrhea has no response to NSAIDs. What is the most appropriate next therapy?

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with precocious puberty and breast development since age 6. What is the most likely cause?

Correct Answer (A)

Idiopathic precocious puberty

Explanation: Constitutional (idiopathic) precocious puberty is the most common cause of early puberty with normal progression of pubertal milestones (e.g., breast development). McCune-Albright syndrome involves café-au-lait spots and bone lesions, hypothyroidism is a rare cause of precocious puberty, and adrenal hyperplasia causes virilization.

Smooth muscle cells

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a rapidly growing ovarian mass and elevated AFP levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: Yolk sac tumours, a type of germ cell tumour, are associated with elevated AFP levels and typically present as rapidly growing masses in younger women. Epithelial tumours are linked with CA-125, granulosa cell tumours with inhibin, and serous cystadenomas are benign.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman with RPL tests positive for lupus anticoagulant. What is the most appropriate treatment per ESHRE guidelines?

Low-dose aspirin + heparin

questions.text: Shown appearance on cerebral angiography is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Moya moya disease
Moya moya disease is characterized by progressive stenosis or occlusion of the internal carotid arteries and their main branches, leading to the development of a network of tiny, fragile collateral vessels that attempt to compensate for reduced blood flow. On cerebral angiography, this results in a characteristic "puff of smoke" or "cloud-like" appearance, which is the hallmark of Moya moya disease. This angiographic pattern is diagnostic and reflects the abnormal collateral circulation.

questions.text: Identify the type of MRI image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

FLAIR image
FLAIR (Fluid Attenuated Inversion Recovery) MRI is a specialized T2-weighted sequence in which the signal from free fluid, especially cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), is suppressed or nulled. This allows better visualization of lesions or abnormalities located near fluid spaces, such as periventricular white matter lesions commonly seen in conditions like multiple sclerosis. In FLAIR images, pathological lesions appear hyperintense (bright), while CSF appears dark, providing clear contrast that helps in early detection of subtle abnormalities.

questions.text: The given finding in MRI is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Joubert syndrome
Joubert syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a distinctive malformation of the brainstem and cerebellum, visible on MRI as the “molar tooth sign.” This sign represents the thickened and elongated superior cerebellar peduncles along with a deep interpeduncular fossa, giving the midbrain a shape reminiscent of a molar tooth. This MRI finding is highly specific and pathognomonic for Joubert syndrome. Patients typically present with developmental delay, hypotonia, abnormal eye movements, and breathing irregularities.

questions.text: The following x-ray was done on a patient with pulmonary tuberculosis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Right upper lobe collapse
Right upper lobe collapse is a common complication seen in pulmonary tuberculosis. On chest X-ray, it typically presents with volume loss in the right upper lung field, leading to elevation of the horizontal fissure and shifting of the mediastinum toward the affected side. There may also be increased opacity in the upper zone, crowding of the ribs, and elevation of the right hilum. This pattern is characteristic because the right upper lobe bronchus is often obstructed by tuberculous inflammation or fibrosis, leading to lobar collapse.

questions.text: The IVP imaging of a 30 year old woman is given. Diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Medullary sponge kidney

Medullary sponge kidney (MSK) is a congenital disorder characterized by cystic dilatation of the collecting ducts in one or both kidneys. On intravenous pyelogram (IVP), it classically shows a “paintbrush” or “brush-like” appearance due to contrast filling the dilated medullary collecting ducts. This pattern is highly suggestive of MSK. Patients may present with hematuria, recurrent urinary tract infections, or nephrocalcinosis. The IVP typically shows multiple tiny contrast-filled outpouchings or ectatic ducts in the renal medulla.

choices.text: Loss of normal shoulders of the subglottic airway
Thickening of aryepiglottic folds and the epiglottis
Multiple luminal soft tissue irregularities in trachea

questions.text:
A 20-month-old male infant is referred to the emergency department with a high pitched, barky cough and in mild respiratory distress, following a few-day course of upper respiratory tract symptoms with low-grade fever. A respiratory virus film array is positive for parainfluenza virus.
Which of the following radiographic findings would you expect in this infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Loss of normal shoulders of the subglottic airway
Laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) is generally a clinical diagnosis and is supported by the facts presented in this scenario. However, you might choose to perform a chest radiograph or lateral neck film if other diagnostic possibilities are under consideration. In croup, you would most likely see loss of the normal shoulders of the subglottic airway giving the characteristic steeple sign. It is best seen in the anteroposterior (AP) view of the chest. Keep in mind that it can be absent in croup and be present in other inflammatory conditions of the upper airway. Clinical context is key.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy presents to your office with 3 episodes of “something hanging from his bottom” after bowel movements over the past few months. His parents describe it as a pink or purple, donut-shaped mass. It usually reduces by itself after a few minutes. The patient often has hard stools, with occasional episodes of foul-smelling, loose stool. There is never any rectal bleeding. The last time it occurred, his mother had to push it back in herself. The family is very concerned this is a sign of another serious disease. You suspect this is rectal prolapse. In a child with rectal prolapse, which initial diagnostic test should be considered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sweat chloride
Functional constipation and prolonged straining during defecation is the most common cause of rectal prolapse, followed by chronic diarrhea caused by enteric and parasitic infections such as Trichuris trichiura. Cystic fibrosis (CF), malnutrition, polyps, and conditions leading to pelvic floor weakness are other common etiologies.
Prevalence of rectal prolapse is high (up to 19% in one study) in cystic fibrosis patients as compared to the general population, and initial screening with sweat chloride test is necessary to rule out CF.

choices.text: Rectal prolapse is most common complication after treatment

Generalized multifocal spike and wave pattern

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl is brought to your clinic, because her mother is concerned that the child might have ADHD. Teachers have noticed that she stares off into space multiple times a day. At times she stops reading in the middle of a sentence and does not remember when or why she stopped; this occurs multiple times a week. You suspect absence seizures and request an EEG.
What is the classic EEG finding seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

3 Hz generalized spike and wave pattern
The classic presentation of absence epilepsy includes characteristic 3 Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG. 4–6 Hz polyspike and wave pattern is seen in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy, which presents in adolescence with myoclonic and/or generalized tonic clonic seizures

choices.text: Rhythmic lip smacking associated with nystagmus and generalized transient hypotonia
Focal motor activity associated with an anatomic spread (“march”) activity with consciousness fully maintained
Sudden flexion of the neck, trunk, and arms followed by abrupt extension of the neck and trunk, with abduction or adduction of the arms or legs
Impaired consciousness associated with generalized bilateral tonic-clonic motor activity
Focal motor activity associated with an anatomic spread (“march”) activity with impaired consciousness

questions.text:
Following hospitalization for a first-time seizure, a 4-month-old has an EEG that is read as “very high-voltage, random, slow waves and spikes in all cortical areas that are consistent with hypsarrhythmia.”
Which of the following best describes the type of seizure activity commonly associated with these EEG results?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sudden flexion of the neck, trunk, and arms followed by abrupt extension of the neck and trunk, with abduction or adduction of the arms or legs
Infantile spasms are characterized by hypsarrhythmia on EEG. Hypsarrhythmia or “mountainous arrhythmia” is characterized by high-voltage, dyssynchronous, chaotic, slow wave and spike activity in all cortical areas. Seizure activity, which often follows arousal, may include flexor spasms, characterized by a sudden flexion of the neck, trunk, arms, and legs associated with contraction of the abdominal muscles; extensor spasms, characterized by abrupt extension of the neck and trunk, with abduction or adduction of the arms or legs; or mixed spasms, consisting of flexion of the neck, trunk, and arms, and extension of the legs.

choices.text: Brownish-gold discoloration of limbus of the cornea and emotional lability

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl complains of a 5-day history of pain in her right arm, which 1 began after playing baseball with her older brothers. Evaluation includes a plain radiograph of her right arm, which reveals a lucent lesion with a homogeneous matrix resembling a “ground glass” appearance due to loss of the normal trabecular pattern in the shaft of the humerus. These findings are often associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Café-au-lait spots and precocious puberty
The patient’s findings are often associated with café-au-lait spots and precocious puberty. She has evidence of fibrous dysplasia, a disorder characterized by radiolucent regions of immature woven bone that do not differentiate into mature lamellar bone. The femur, tibia, humerus, ribs, and mandible/maxilla are most often affected; multiple adjacent sites (polyostotic fibrous
dysplasia) may also be affected. Bone disease may be clinically silent or associated with bony
deformities, pain, joint stiffness, swelling, or pathologic fractures. Polyostotic fibrous
dysplasia, precocious puberty, and café-au-lait spots are characteristic of McCune-Albright
syndrome.

questions.text: How do you define precocious puberty in girls?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 
Less than 8 yrs

Precocious puberty is defined as development of pubertal changes before the age of 8 years in girls along with an increase in goandotropin and or sex steroid, accelerated somatic development and bone age.

choices.text: Helmet and burr cells on a peripheral smear

questions.text:
The parents of a 14-month-old child present to the emergency department with the concern that their son has not had a wet diaper in more than 12 hours. They describe him as having frequent episodes of loose stools, several of which appeared to have contained blood. He is irritable and pale on physical examination. Laboratory findings include elevated levels of blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine. He is hospitalized for dehydration and possible sepsis. A stool culture is subsequently positive for Escherichia coli O157:H7.

Which of the following laboratory findings is likely to be identified during additional evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Helmet and burr cells on a peripheral smear

The patient has hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). It is most often caused by gastroenteritis due to Escherichia coli O157:H7. Toxins produced by E. coli are first absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and then cause endothelial cell injury in the renal glomeruli. Endothelial cell injury also affects red blood cells, leading to the formation of helmet and burr cells, which may be identified on peripheral smear.

questions.text: Which of the following does not suggest a Pre-Renal AKI instead of a Renal-AKI?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

choices.text: Acetaminophen, by activating calcium channels and vasoconstricting
Acetylsalicylic acid, by blocking calcium channels and vasodilating
Ibuprofen, by activating cyclooxygenase-1 and increasing prostaglandin synthesis
Indomethacin, by inhibiting cyclooxygenase-1 and decreasing prostaglandin synthesis

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate born at 26 weeks’ gestation is in the neonatal intensive care unit. He remains intubated, is receiving mechanical ventilatory support, and has a fractional inspired oxygen concentration of 80% to 90%. He is receiving nothing by mouth because of gastric feeding intolerance. On physical examination, he is tachycardic with a continuous machinelike murmur audible throughout the precordium. Chest radiography shows increased pulmonary vascular markings bilaterally. His creatinine level has been slowly increasing during the last 2 days. The decision is made to treat the neonate’s condition pharmacologically. Of the following, the BEST treatment for this neonate is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The premature neonate in the vignette has signs of pulmonary overcirculation (prolonged need for mechanical ventilatory support and increased pulmonary vascular markings on chest radiograph) and decreased systemic perfusion (tachycardia, increasing creatinine levels, and feeding intolerance) caused by a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) inhibit the COX-1 enzyme, leading to decreased synthesis of prostaglandins as well as constriction and possible closure of a PDA. Conversely, a continuous infusion of prostaglandin can reopen or maintain the patency of a ductus arteriosus and is used to manage critical congenital heart disease.
Indomethacin and ibuprofen are NSAIDs used to pharmacologically close a PDA. Both decrease, not increase, prostaglandin synthesis
